title: Bishop Monkton Ings
text:
Bishop Monkton Ings is a <a href="Site%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">Site of Special Scientific Interest</a>, or SSSI, situated east of <a href="Bishop%20Monkton">Bishop Monkton</a> village in <a href="North%20Yorkshire">North Yorkshire</a>, England. It consists mostly of <a href="marsh">marsh</a>y, <a href="calcareous%20grassland">calcareous grassland</a>, with some <a href="Deciduous">broadleaved</a> woodland, and some <a href="fen">fen</a> alongside the two watercourses which run through the site. This varied <a href="wetland">wetland</a> forms a <a href="habitat">habitat</a> for a variety of plants, including the semi-parasitic marsh lousewort "(<a href="Pedicularis">Pedicularis palustris</a>)".
Site history.
(An <a href="ings">ings</a> is a <a href="water%20meadow">water meadow</a> or <a href="marsh">marsh</a>. The word is of <a href="Old%20Norse">Norse</a> origin, entering the English language in the <a href="Danelaw">Danelaw</a> period. It appears in a number of place names in <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a>, <a href="Cumbria">Cumbria</a> and <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a>).
In 1807 the Ings, then measuring 4 <a href="acres">acres</a>, 1 <a href="rod%20%28unit%29">rod</a>, 6 <a href="pole%20%28unit%29">pole</a>s and described as meadow, was put up for auction by the landowner William Wells. The nearby Broad Close, measuring 1 acre, 2 rods and 17 poles and also described as meadow, may have been another part of the present SSSI site. At this time the adjacent <a href="common%20land">common land</a> was undergoing <a href="enclosure">enclosure</a>, and also for sale.
Part of this site was sold in 1862 while tenanted by farmer George Heath (born ca. 1832), who was farming 132 acres with his brothers Edward and Robert. It was described as "a <a href="Field%20%28agriculture%29">close</a> of grass land called Ings Close, with a small <a href="willow">willow</a> garth therein, situated in the ings of Bishop Monkton, and containing 3 <a href="acre">acre</a>s and 1 <a href="rood%20%28unit%29">rood</a> or thereabouts." 
In 1883 the Ings was sold again, while in the tenancy of Mary Heath (born ca.1821), likely a relative of George Heath who was now farming in <a href="Hunslet">Hunslet</a>, Leeds. This part of the site was at that time called the <a href="Water-meadow">Ings</a> Field, comprising two enclosures of "rich feeding grassland" with the Ings <a href="Drainage">Drain</a> running through it. It was measured as four acres, one <a href="rod%20%28unit%29">rod</a> and five <a href="pole%20%28unit%20of%20length%29">pole</a>s.
Site location and designation.
Bishop Monkton Ings is a biological <a href="Site%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">Site of Special Scientific Interest</a> (SSSI). It lies to the south of <a href="Ripon">Ripon</a>, North Yorkshire. Access is via the muddy Ings Lane public footpath running east from <a href="Bishop%20Monkton">Bishop Monkton</a> village to the north-west corner of the site. The track is part of Ripon Rowel Walk. There is no vehicular access, and no facilities. The watercourses Holbeck and Ings Drain run through the site, which contains <a href="deciduous%20trees">deciduous</a> woodland, "species-rich marshy grassland subject to winter flooding" and some fen alongside the two streams. 
The site was <a href="SSSI%20notification">notified</a> as an SSSI on 1 October 1986 for its "diverse range of wetland habitats" including woodland, and also because <a href="wetland">wetland</a> such as this was once widespread, but is now under threat from <a href="Land%20development">land improvement</a> and the <a href="drainage">drainage</a> requirements of adjacent agricultural land and settlements.
Significant site content.
"Note": Unless otherwise stated, images of flora and fauna in this article are for illustrative purposes only, and were not taken at this site.
Flora.
The marshy grassland benefits from sporadic winter floods, resulting in a variety of plant life. It has <a href="Lotus%20pedunculatus">greater bird's foot trefoil</a>, <a href="Hypericum%20tetrapterum">square stalked St John's wort</a>, <a href="Lathyrus%20pratensis">meadow vetchling</a>, <a href="Vicia%20cracca">tufted vetch</a>, <a href="Lychnis%20flos-cuculi">ragged robin</a>, <a href="Sanguisorba%20officinalis">great burnet</a>, <a href="Angelica%20sylvestris">wild angelica</a> and <a href="Valerian%20%28herb%29">common valerian</a>. More common species here are <a href="Caltha%20palustris">marsh marigold</a>, <a href="Filipendula%20ulmaria">meadowsweet</a>, hard rush "(<a href="Juncus">Juncus inflexus</a>)", <a href="Juncus%20effusus">soft rush</a> and <a href="Carex%20acutiformis">lesser pond sedge</a>.
Near the springs, plants benefit from the <a href="aquifer">aquifer</a>'s <a href="calcareous">calcareous</a> minerals, so the following plants grow here: marsh lousewort "(<a href="Pedicularis">Pedicularis palustris</a>)", marsh valerian "(<a href="Valeriana">Valeriana dioica</a>)", <a href="Carex%20panicea">carnation sedge</a>, <a href="Carex%20flacca">glaucous sedge</a>, <a href="Carex%20nigra">common sedge</a>, <a href="Carex%20disticha">brown sedge</a>, <a href="Schoenus%20nigricans">black bogrush</a>, other <a href="Cyperaceae">cyperaceous</a> species and <a href="bryophytes">bryophytes</a>. The most common plant here is the <a href="Juncus%20subnodulosus">blunt-flowered rush</a>.
On raised ground in the south of the site there is grassland with <a href="Soil%20pH">neutral</a> (as opposed to <a href="calcareous">calcareous</a>) soil. Here is found <a href="Ajuga%20reptans">bugle</a>, <a href="Sanguisorba%20officinalis">great burnet</a>. <a href="Achillea%20ptarmica">sneezewort</a>, <a href="Succisa%20pratensis">devil's bit scabious</a>, <a href="Conopodium%20majus">pignut</a> and <a href="Ranunculus%20repens">creeping buttercup</a>. These flowers grow among grasses such as <a href="Deschampsia%20cespitosa">tufted hair grass</a>, <a href="Holcus%20lanatus">Yorkshire fog</a> and <a href="Anthoxanthum%20odoratum">sweet vernal grass</a>.
There are three patches of deciduous woodland on the site. Under the trees in the dampest places are <a href="Angelica%20sylvestris">wild angelica</a> and <a href="Filipendula%20ulmaria">meadowsweet</a>. On the slightly raised and drier ground can be found a number of plants including <a href="Geum%20urbanum">wood avens</a>, <a href="Silene%20dioica">red campion</a> and <a href="Mercurialis%20perennis">dog's mercury</a>. <a href="Viburnum%20opulus">Guelder rose</a> is frequent here. The trees include <a href="Salix%20pentandra">bay willow</a>, <a href="Salix%20fragilis">crack willow</a>, <a href="Fraxinus%20excelsior">ash</a> and <a href="Alnus%20glutinosa">alder</a>.
An important habitat here is the fen alongside the watercourses. Here are <a href="Phalaris%20arundinacea">reed canary grass</a>, <a href="Glyceria%20maxima">reed sweet grass</a> and the reed "<a href="Phragmites">Phragmites australis</a>".
Fauna.
<a href="Common%20snipe">Common snipe</a> and <a href="Eurasian%20curlew">curlew</a> are among the waders which breed in the fen.
Maintenance.
Annual light <a href="grazing">grazing</a> is required, by cattle, <a href="pony">ponies</a> or <a href="hill%20farming">hill</a> sheep, to maintain a rich and varied diversity of <a href="herb">herb</a>s and other <a href="Biome">biota</a> on the <a href="grassland">grassland</a>. The purpose of this is to prevent a build-up of tall grasses and dead vegetation, which in turn would inhibit diverse plant growth, and overshadow weaker plants. Grazing should occur between late spring and early autumn if there are no ground-nesting birds there. The size and function of existing drains should be maintained, and some <a href="scrubland">scrub</a> and hedge should be retained. Changes to drainage, and the use of <a href="Fertilizer">fertiliser</a>, <a href="herbicide">herbicide</a>s and <a href="pesticide">pesticide</a>s, are strongly discouraged because they would change the quality and <a href="biodiversity">diversity</a> of the present plant and animal life.
Development and risk assessment.
Both units of <a href="fen">fen</a>, <a href="marsh">marsh</a> and <a href="swamp">swamp</a> were assessed by <a href="Natural%20England">Natural England</a> in 2011. The first unit was judged to be in favourable condition, with some <a href="Crataegus">hawthorn</a> <a href="Shrubland">scrub</a> clearance required, although this section passed the assessment due to a good <a href="Biodiversity">diversity of species</a>, and the grassland was in good condition. The second unit was judged "unfavourable but recovering", because hawthorn scrub was encroaching onto grassland and fen. The assessor found <a href="Jacobaea%20vulgaris">ragwort</a> scattered across the site. No explanation is given for the mention in the assessment of ragwort, but it is possible that a balance had to be made between its situation as a controlled plant, with toxicity to cattle and ponies, and its advantages as a pollinator and ability to host certain insect larvae, such as that of the <a href="cinnabar%20moth">cinnabar moth</a>. In the UK, the cinnabar moth is a <a href="Priority%20effect">priority species</a>.
In October 2016, this site was assessed for any potential damaging effect of mining for minerals, for a period up to 2030. In 2016 the authorities were seeking more sites for sand and gravel quarries, besides the sites that were already being worked. In 2018 a permit was granted for a poultry farm next to Bishop Monkton Ings, with the requirement that the poultry and the Ings be separated from one another by trees and a fence.
See also.
Other SSSIs in the <a href="Harrogate">Harrogate</a> region are: <a href="Brimham%20Rocks">Brimham Rocks</a>, <a href="Cow%20Myers%20%28wetland%29">Cow Myers</a>, <a href="Farnham%20Mires">Farnham Mires</a>, <a href="Hack%20Fall%20Wood">Hack Fall Wood</a>, <a href="Hay-a-Park%20Gravel%20Pit">Hay-a-Park</a>, <a href="Kirk%20Deighton%20SSSI">Kirk Deighton</a> <a href="Mar%20Field%20Fen">Mar Field Fen</a>, <a href="Quarry%20Moor">Quarry Moor</a>, and <a href="Ripon%20Parks">Ripon Parks</a>.
